titlestmt.subtitle: Papers of Kurt Vonnegut, 1941-2007, at the Lilly Library, Indiana University
titlestmt.author: Alyssa Mertka

did.abstract: The Vonnegut mss., 1941-2007, consists of the papers of novelist Kurt Vonnegut, 1922-2007.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Kurt Vonnegut, 1922-2007, was an American novelist. He was born in Indianapolis, Indiana on November 11, 1922. He attended Shortridge High School in Indianapolis, where he wrote for the Shortridge High School Echo, one of the few daily high school newspapers in the country. At the urging of his father, Vonnegut attended Cornell University to study chemistry and biology. While at Cornell, Vonnegut worked for the Cornell Daily Sun, even writing his own column. However, before he could complete his degree, he enlisted in the Army. While serving during World War II, Vonnegut survived the firebombing of Dresden as a prisoner of war, an experience that would later influence his novel Slaughterhouse Five (1969). Vonnegut had seven children in all, three from his first marriage to Jane Cox, his three nephews, and a daughter he adopted with his second wife, Jill Krementz. Vonnegut lived in New York with Jill until his death on April 11, 2007.

His first published work was a piece of short fiction "Report on the Barnhouse Effect" which appeared in Collier's, Feb. 1950. Over the years his short stories and articles have appeared in many magazines, but he is best known for his novels, the first of which, Player Piano, was published in 1952. Vonnegut has also written for both the stage and screen, and many of his works have been adapted to film, television and theater.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Much of the general correspondence is from colleagues, friends and fans. Along with major works the Writings section contains screenplays, teleplays, play scripts and many short stories and articles. The Farber files are those of Vonnegut's agent and lawyer Donald C. Farber. They consist of contracts, correspondence and notes concerning translation, performance, and publication rights and permissions. The Publishing Records include royalty reports, contracts and items related to the publication of his works. Miscellaneous items include: awards and trophies, artwork, family related materials, school papers, photographs, and clippings. The additions are materials received since 2002.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into the following series: I. General correspondence; II. Writings; III. Farber files; IV. Publishing records; V. Miscellaneous; VI. Additions; VII. Additions II.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Vonnegut mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See Vonnegut mss. II, Vonnegut mss. III, and Vonnegut mss. IV, also located at the Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The general correspondence is mostly with Kurt Vonnegut and is divided into an alphabetical file, rejection letters and a chronological file. Correspondence with Donald C. Farber concerning contracts, translation, performance, and publication rights and permissions are filed in the Farber files. Occasionally letters were left with related writings or in other miscellaneous sections.

did.unittitle: Arranged alphabetically with occasional letters from Vonnegut filed with correspondent. Mostly with colleagues and friends. Correspondents are:
50 rejection slips from various magazines. Mostly printed slips; two or three with notes explaining the rejection
Correspondence includes fan letters, invitations to speak, or regarding various projects

odd.head: General
odd.p: Arranged chronologically.

odd.head: General
odd.p: See also: Farber files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Organized into the following sections: major works; reviews; short stories and articles; speeches. A few letters to Vonnegut from a publisher or editor are filed with manuscripts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes books, play scripts, screenplays, television scripts, and librettos. Arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Adam. Typescript of screenplay adapted by Robert Bassing, second draft
Screenplay adapted from short story by Tom Cotter
Teleplay adapted by Stan Daniels from short story
Typescript of synopsis and play script
Between Time and Timbuktu ...a musical. Book and lyrics by Andrew Barrett, music by Neil Ginsberg (Based on the works of Vonnegut). Typescript of play; program
Photocopy of the final corrected typescript, 319 pages

Breakfast in Bethlehem: A one-act play for children at Christmastime. Four typescript copies, ca. 20p. each; four mimeograph copies, 8p. each. Contains some correspondence. Published as "The First Christmas Morning" in Better Homes and Gardens.
Original title: Goodbye, Blue Monday. Corrected typescript drafts of various sections
Vonnegut's carbon copy of his final project for the Program in Creative Writing at the University of Iowa, titled:Goodbye, Blue Monday: The Autograph of a Pontiac dealer in the American Middle-West

Typescript. Corrected in autograph, with Vonnegut's original line drawings throughout. Large unpublished section with drawings. Additional typescript, not corrected, perhaps from earlier or later drafts
First draft of screenplay by Paul Golding and Peter Bergman
Stageplay adapted by Robert Egan. Typescript
A play for seven actors, by Bruce Pribram
The Chemistry Professor. (based on Jekyll and Hyde story). Play, 1978 (see also: Shilling Shocker)
Class of '45. Skit for "peace project." 2 copies
D.P.. Carbon typescript of play, with corrections; teleplay
Typescript, corrected in autograph. Labeled "Rough ms."
Typescript, corrected in autograph. Labeled "Finished ms."
Photocopy of corrected typescript. Labeled "Summer 1981 revise xerox."
Emory Beck. Typescript of play by Robert B. Ruthman and Vonnegut
The Euphio Question. Screenplay adapted by Jeffrey Cohen. Outline only
Typescript, corrected in autograph. Titled: In the Capital of the World: A Collage.
Typescript, incorporating scenes from the play "Make Up Your Mind," plus Appendix, lightly corrected. Titled: The Hocus Pocus Laundromat: Freethinker Papers
Typescript photocopy, incorporating scenes from the play "Make Up Your Mind," plus Appendix. Titled: The Hocus Pocus Laundromat: Freethinker Papers
Typescript. Titled: The Hocus Pocus Laundromat

Photocopy of corrected typescript, 2 copies. Labeled "Complete as of 2.8.91."

The Foster Portfolio. Outline of script, written by Jeremy Hole
Galapagos. Introduction to Franklin Library edition
Girl Pool. Typescript and carbon typescript of play (see also: Short stories and articles: Girl Pool)
Galley proof. Corrected in autograph. Stamped "Master Proof..."
Galley proof of God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater (published)
Three typescripts and photocopy of "God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater: A New Musical" by Howard Ashman, Alan Menken, and Dennis Green. Dated:
Grieve My Lord No More. Typescript of play
Typescript, corrected in autograph, of an early draft of the play in novel form. Additional pages of corrected typescript. Titled:The Fur-Lined Bouillon Cup
Photocopy of early draft of play. Titled: The Fur-Lined Bouillon Cup, or a Woman Is Not an Electric Scoreboard
Two different typescript versions, corrected in autograph, of an early draft of the play. Titled:Penelope. Additional uncorrected or very lightly corrected typescript drafts.
Photocopies of Acts 2 and 3, two photographs of production and cover letter from Thomas A. Power of early version of play entitled: Penelope as performed at University of Maine

Two different typescript versions, corrected in autograph, of an early draft of the play entitled:Something Borrowed. Additional uncorrected or very lightly corrected typescript drafts of various sections

Typescript photocopy, rev.typescript, rev. typescript, labeled "Final script heavily corrected in autograph; typescript, labeled "Final script lightly corrected in autograph; typescript, labeled "Revised final script with photocopied and original corrections
Photocopy of a revised ending, with a photocopy of a letter for Vonnegut to Dusty Hughestypescript of another revised ending, with an original letter from Vonnegut to Don Farber
Heidi Again. Two page synopsis and typescript of play
The Helmer Case. Nora. Play. Autograph pages; typescript; and mimeograph
Hey Earth--We're Watching You. Synopsis and proposed cast list for play by Vonnegut and Dick Feldman

L'Histoire du Soldat. Music by Igor Stravinsky, libretto by Vonnegut. Six typescripts; page proofs; two related letters; program for performance at Webster University, advertisement for the concert performance at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, Thursday
Typescript, corrected in autograph. With a second version of chapter twelve.
Typescript of the preface to the Franklin Library edition
The Hoosier Symphony. Synopsis and various typescript versions of play
I Know What I Like. Typescript synopsis of play
I'll Go to Sleep in Dresden. Typescript of play (incomplete)
Several early typescript drafts, entitled:Mary Kathleen O'Looney or Unacceptable Air. mostly rewrites of the beginning chapters, corrected in autograph
Early typescript, entitled: Mary Kathleen O'Looney (Or, Fats in a Windstorm). corrected in autograph
Typescript, Mary Kathleen O'Looney (Or, Fats in a Windstorm). retitled: Jailbird by Vonnegut in autograph
Galley proof, photocopy, with autograph corrections. Labeled "Auth set 1st pass...not shooting copy."
Jonah. Two typescripts of Act I; typescript of fragments of Act II
Long Walk to Forever. (a short musical). Music and lyrics by Jeff Lazarus
Make Up Your Mind. Typescripts for different versions of play, three of the typescripts corrected in autograph: four undated
Money Talks. Synopsis of play (see also: Short stories...: Money Talks)
Mother Night. Galley proof of Mother Night; mock-up of trade edition; introduction for 1966 Harper & Row hardback edition.
Next Door. Second draft of script, adapted by Jeremy Hole
Player Piano. Galley proof of Player Piano. A few pages missing

The Sirens of Titan. Typescript. Corrected in autograph. Fifteen bundles of rolled-up leaves, with a few pages of typescript drafts. One bundle for Chap. 1-5, 7-9, 11, two for Chap. 6 and 12 [no Chap. 10]. Typescript of a new introduction, 1989.
Slapstick. Five typescripts of screenplay, lyrics to "Lonesome No More"
Corrected typescript drafts of various sections of the novel including three radically different versions of the beginning chapter

(play). Typescript of synopsis and revised script, dated brochure/order form for performance in Munich; ticket stubs and stagebill for performance in Chicago at the Steppenwolf Theatre; undated clipping of review from the London Financial Times

Sun Moon Star . (juvenile fiction). Page proof and printer's copy

Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow. Script
Wampeters, Foma, and Granfalloons. Final draft, made up of typescript pages, magazine clippings, and photocopies, corrected throughout in autograph, with printer's notes in margins
Welcome to the Monkey House. Script of Act I
Who Am I This Time?. Two scripts; mimeo script adapted by Aaron Posner
The Windup Man. Three typescripts of television script
Introduction to story by Frank Conroy for Gentleman's Quarterly
Book reviews written by Vonnegut for the following: The Disney Version by Richard Schickel; The Triumph by John Kenneth Galbraith; Unless Peace Comes edited by Nigel Calder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains drafts, final typescripts, and related materials. Many accompanying envelopes are covered in Vonnegut's characteristic doodles; some list (in another hand) dates for submission of the story, and, if accepted, the amount paid by various magazines. Arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contain the files of Donald C. Farber in his capacity as Vonnegut's lawyer and literary agent. Arranged alphabetically by work. Includes: correspondence, contracts, notes, and other materials. The correspondence includes requests to publish, translate, or produce on stage or film various works. "Notes" refers to Farber's and his secretaries' handwritten notes. (See also: I. General correspondence)

did.unittitle: Between Time and Timbuktu. Correspondence: notes
Breakfast of Champions. Correspondence: contracts; notes; promotional material
Deadeye Dick. Correspondence: notes; promotional materials
Fates Worse Than Death. Correspondence: notes
Notes; promotional materials and playbill; Rosewater Partnership
Happy Birthday, Wanda June. Correspondence: contracts; notes; programs, poster, set plan & property plot
Hocus Pocus. Correspondence: notes; publicity schedule
Make Up Your Mind. Correspondence: contracts; notes; programs
Rage and Outrage. Correspondence: contracts; notes; story outlines
The Sirens of Titan. Correspondence: contracts; notes; programs
Slaughterhouse Five. Correspondence: contracts; movie press kit; notes
Wampeters, Foma, and Grandfalloons. Correspondence:contracts; notes
Correspondence: contracts; D.P. tear-sheet; notes; TV series - cast and crew lists
Materials concerning contract negotiations and foreign publication rights, miscellaneous contracts, and royalty reports

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes: "An account of the ancestry of Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. by an ancient friend of his family, Indianapolis, 1970"; passports; clippings; copies of entries to various biographical sources

odd.head: General
odd.p: "Thirteen haiku composed by James C. Adams, Jr., for the seventieth birthday of his uncle Kurt Vonnegut, Jr., November 11th, 1992..."

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes: several original drawings by Vonnegut, catalog of his work, articles about his artwork, materials concerning an exhibition at the Margo Feiden Galleries in New York; two drawings of Vonnegut signed "GR81" (probably drawn from photographs).

odd.head: General
odd.p: Two copies and associated materials

odd.head: General
odd.p: (later: Cosby Bureau International). Includes materials pertaining to speaking engagements

odd.head: General
odd.p: Description, rules, correspondence, and diagrams in Vonnegut's hand for the boardgame G.H.Q. (General Headquarters) invented by Vonnegut. With the original typed draft of a letter to Mr. Saalfield at Saalfield Game Company in Ohio

odd.head: General
odd.p: Typescript, over 100 pages. Part of a novel by Vonnegut's ex-wife, Jane Cox

odd.head: General
odd.p: List of Board of Directors, November 1988

did.unittitle: Photocopy of Vonnegut's final high school report card and history of PS43. Both enclosed in letter from Robert Weide at "Whyaduck Productions" to Vonnegut

Anthropology 220, 230, 345, 499 and unidentified classes. Worksheets, notes and papers with notes and doodles throughout; notes, assignments, and charts; papers and exams, some with teacher's comments and grades.
History 201. Syllabus and Problems. University of Chicago Bookstore, June 1945. 153 pages. Vonnegut's college textbook, with his annotations and doodles. Various related pages laid in

Thesis, tentatively titled "Mythologies of North American Nativistic Movements." Removed from binder. Summer, 1947. Notes, charts, annotated pages, with doodles throughout. Laid in are a couple of notes from his advisor and an outline for the project
Thesis "Fluctuations Between Good and Ill Fortune in Simple Tales" written at the Writer's Workshop at University of Iowa. Four copies

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials relating to membership

odd.head: General
odd.p: paid bills, investment information, life insurance, retirement trust, etc.

odd.head: General
odd.p: ephemera, including maps, Vonnegut's handwritten itineraries and schedules, tickets, visas, etc

odd.head: General
odd.p: (KV's uncle). Letter to Alex from Vonnegut, Nov. 28, 1947 accompanied by anecdote about it written by Vonnegut

odd.head: General
odd.p: (KV's brother). Material relating to his death, Apr. 25, 1997

odd.head: General
odd.p: (KV's son). Color photocopy of painting with description of why he paints

odd.head: General

odd.head: General
odd.p: Copies of family pictures (9); Vonnegut, et al. taken at breakfast at Gracie Mansion honoring President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, 1990; Vonnegut taken at United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, 1986; scrapbook: photographs taken at Vonnegut's 60th birthday celebration, Nov. 11, 1982; Bound volume: photographs taken in Prague, 1985; Scrapbook: "Vonneguts (from Aunt Raye's Scrapbook)," mostly clippings, a few photographs(see also: Box 23)

odd.head: General
odd.p: Mostly reviews of Vonnegut's books and some about him

odd.head: General
odd.p: Drama Desk Award, 1970-1971; Grammy Award nomination, 1973; The John Steinbeck Award, 1992; Man of the Year award from General Electric; recognition from Indiana Arts Commission, The New School, Phi Beta Kappa, and The American Civil Liberties Union; honorary degrees from Hobart and William Smith Colleges, University of Rhode Island, and University of Chicago, University of Evansville; Television-Radio Writers' Annual Award, Writers Guild of America for "Auf Wiedersehen, 1957-1958 (see also: Box 26)

odd.head: General
odd.p: Trophies: Distinguished Artist Award, North Shore Community Arts Center, Great Neck, NY 1977; Best Science Fiction Film, 1972, Slaughterhouse Five; International Poetry Forum, 11-17-71; Friends of the Chicago Library, Freedom to Read Award Presented by Christie Hefner, Dec. 4, 1982; Annual Playboy Editorial Award, 1976; ILLOWA Library Association, 1989 Intellectual Freedom Award.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The Freethinker's Calendar, 1989. Vonnegut's birthday noted on Nov. 11

odd.head: General
odd.p: photographs taken at Butler University, honorary degree presentation, May 11, 1996

odd.head: General
